intro: Cymopterus corrugatus var. coulteri, commonly known as Coulter's spikeroot, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and often have a distinctive corrugated texture, while its flowers are small and white or pale green. It is often used in native plant gardens due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
